The more money you want to invest, the less stocks are available for investing, and the more difficult it is to increase your rewards.

The less money you want to invest, the faster your broker costs will eat up your rewards. This also holds for more frequent trading and larger portfolio sizes. However, larger portfolio sizes offer you a chance to better spread your risks.

For smaller and mid-sized investments, there often exist game plans that expect better-fitting risks and rewards than those programs offered by professional parties that let you participate in larger funds accommodating some kind of averaged risk and reward profile.
In this field of opposing forces, you have the choice of ending up in a straitjacket of averages or quantifying your own choices to let them optimally bloom.
